cognitive.title: Understanding comes from cognitive effort
cognitive.subtitle: Not from simple exposure to information
cognitive.description:
Cognitive sciences are very clear on one point: seeing information is not understanding it.

The brain learns durably when it is active, not passive. Manual recording requires:

‚Ä¢ identifying the expense,
‚Ä¢ categorizing it,
‚Ä¢ comparing it to an intention (budget, goal),
‚Ä¢ consciously accepting it.

This mechanism is close to what's called "learning by doing" or active learning, widely documented in educational psychology.

‚û°Ô∏è Automation removes cognitive effort, therefore deep understanding. Automation creates an illusion of control. It doesn't develop real mastery.

illusion.title: Automation creates an illusion of control
illusion.subtitle: It doesn't develop real mastery
illusion.description:
Numerous studies show that automated tools generate an illusion of mastery:

‚Ä¢ "My accounts are connected"
‚Ä¢ "My expenses are categorized"
‚Ä¢ "I have a dashboard"

But:

‚Ä¢ the user can't explain where their money goes,
‚Ä¢ nor why they deviate from their goals,
‚Ä¢ nor which lever to activate.

This phenomenon is close to passive overconfidence bias, reinforced by automatic systems.

‚û°Ô∏è Automation shifts responsibility to the tool, not to the user.

ritual.title: Ritual transforms finance into behavior
ritual.subtitle: Ritual develops understanding and mastery
ritual.description:
Financial understanding doesn't rely solely on knowledge, but on behavioral habits.

Ritualizing (e.g., a few minutes per day and week) allows:

‚Ä¢ anchoring a conscious routine,
‚Ä¢ creating a regular point of contact with financial reality,
‚Ä¢ transforming an abstract constraint into tangible practice.

Research on habits shows that:

‚Ä¢ conscious repetition is a key factor for lasting change,
‚Ä¢ micro-rituals are more effective than occasional automated reviews.

‚û°Ô∏è Steero doesn't just aim to "show numbers", but also to install a behavior.

emotional.title: Manual logging creates an emotional connection
emotional.subtitle: The key to decision-making
emotional.description:
A manually recorded expense is not neutral:

‚Ä¢ it triggers a micro emotional evaluation,
‚Ä¢ it makes the cost psychologically real,
‚Ä¢ it reinforces the memory of the decision.

It's the same mechanism as:

‚Ä¢ writing goals by hand,
‚Ä¢ noting meals in a food diary,
‚Ä¢ keeping an expense journal.

Studies show that this conscious self-observation significantly improves self-regulation.

‚û°Ô∏è Without minimal friction, there is neither awareness nor real arbitration.

learning.title: Automating too early prevents learning
learning.subtitle: One of the classic mistakes when regaining control
learning.description:
Automation is useful‚Ä¶ after understanding, not before.

In most current apps:

‚Ä¢ the user is bombarded with data,
‚Ä¢ without mental framework,
‚Ä¢ without implicit pedagogy,
‚Ä¢ without appropriation.

Result:

‚Ä¢ quick abandonment,
‚Ä¢ passive consultation,
‚Ä¢ no real progress.

Conversely, Steero adopts a logic similar to learning to drive: first understand and feel, then optimize and automate.

‚û°Ô∏è The goal is not to remove effort, but to make it useful, short, and intentional.

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.discoverHow: Discover how Steero works in practice.

q1.question: Who is Steero for?
q1.answer:
Steero is for anyone who wants to take control of their finances, without becoming an expert or spending hours managing numbers.

Whether you're just starting out or have already tried spreadsheets, budgeting apps, or automated tools, Steero is for you if you're looking for clarity, understandable benchmarks, and a simple framework to move forward over time.

There are no financial prerequisites.

q2.question: What's the difference between Steero and a banking app or aggregator?
q2.answer:
Banking apps and aggregators mainly show what has already happened: balances, transactions, retrospective charts.

Steero takes a different approach. Steero is a steering tool, not just a viewing tool. It allows you to:
‚Ä¢ set a direction (goals)
‚Ä¢ follow a trajectory (budgets, indicators)
‚Ä¢ spot gaps
‚Ä¢ consciously adjust your decisions
‚Ä¢ follow a clear rhythm that guides you

Where other tools inform, Steero helps you understand and act.

q3.question: Does Steero replace my banking app?
q3.answer:
No, and that's not its goal. Your banking app remains essential for paying, checking your accounts, and performing banking operations.

Steero complements it. It allows you to step back, structure your financial vision, and steer what your banking apps don't do: your rituals, your goals, your trajectory, your trade-offs.

In summary: the bank executes, Steero helps you decide.

q1.question: Why doesn't Steero connect to my banks?
q1.answer:
Automate ‚â† Understand. 100% automated tools show numbers, but don't teach. Without cognitive effort, the user sees their finances without mastering them. Common result: illusion of control ‚Üí disengagement ‚Üí abandonment.

Understanding comes from conscious action. Manually recording a transaction forces you to identify the expense, categorize it, and link it to a budget or goal. This micro-effort activates learning and memory. It's the principle of learning by doing: you understand by doing.

Ritual creates lasting behavior. Steero favors a short, regular ritual. Conscious repetition transforms finance into a habit, not a constraint. A habit always beats a forgotten automated dashboard.

q2.question: How long does it take to record my transactions?
q2.answer:
Very little time ‚Äî and much less than you might think.

In reality, most people make a few transactions per day, sometimes only a few per week. With Steero, recording them takes a few seconds. It's not about obsessively logging everything, but capturing the essentials regularly.

Why it's not burdensome:
‚Ä¢ You don't have dozens of lines per day
‚Ä¢ Recurring transactions quickly become natural to enter thanks to transaction templates
‚Ä¢ The action fits into a simple ritual, not a chore

What you gain: you know where you stand without waiting until the end of the month, and you immediately spot where you are thanks to a dynamic budget indicator.

q3.question: Does Steero give financial advice?
q3.answer:
No. And it's intentional.

Steero doesn't provide personalized financial advice and doesn't replace a professional (financial advisor, tax specialist, lawyer).

The analyses, charts, projections, and indicators offered by Steero have an informational and educational purpose: they help you better understand your situation, visualize your trajectory, and step back from your decisions.

They are neither individualized recommendations nor guarantees of performance or results. Steero doesn't decide for you.

q1.question: Is my data secure?
q1.answer:
Yes. Security and respect for your data are priorities.

‚Ä¢ Your data is stored securely
‚Ä¢ Steero doesn't sell your information
‚Ä¢ You remain the owner of your data at all times

Steero is designed as a trusted, sustainable, and respectful tool ‚Äî not as a product based on exploiting your information.

We invite you to read the terms of service before trying.

q2.question: Where is my data stored?
q2.answer:
Your data is hosted on secure servers in Europe, in compliance with current regulations (GDPR).

We use modern encryption technologies and proven security practices to ensure the confidentiality and integrity of your information.

q1.question: Is Steero free?
q1.answer:
Yes, Steero is free for 14 days. This period allows you to discover the tool, use it in your daily life, and check if it naturally fits your way of managing your finances. No pressure ‚Äî you can stop at any time during this period.

And after 14 days? A subscription is required to continue. This subscription helps maintain and improve the solution, ensure a stable experience, and develop new features.

An intentionally accessible price: the main subscription will cost less than ‚Ç¨10 per month ‚Äî the equivalent of a coffee per week, or a few minutes less of mental load each day.

q2.question: How does the waitlist work?
q2.answer:
The waitlist allows you to reserve your spot to access Steero as soon as it launches.

By signing up, you'll be among the first to know when the app opens. You'll receive an email to create your account and start your 14-day free trial.

Registration is free and non-binding.

q3.question: Can I use Steero on mobile?
q3.answer:
Not at the moment ‚Äî and it's a deliberate choice. Steero is designed as a steering tool, not as an app to check between two notifications.

The financial ritual we advocate requires calm and concentration. Understanding a financial trajectory requires depth of information, comparisons, readable indicators, and a global vision.

Mobile is great for quick consultation. It's much less so for thinking, analyzing, and consciously adjusting. Steero is not designed to be "checked", but to be used with intention.

And for the future? Mobile is not excluded, but if it comes one day, it will be to serve steering, not to impoverish it.

q4.question: Will Steero evolve over time?
q4.answer:
Yes, and it's at the heart of the project.

Steero is designed as a long-term product, which evolves gradually to remain simple, relevant, and aligned with users' real needs.

New features will enrich the experience, always with the same philosophy:
‚Ä¢ no unnecessary complexity
‚Ä¢ no automation that dispossesses
‚Ä¢ only what really helps to better steer

Subscriptions are precisely used to maintain this quality and make Steero evolve in the right direction.

1.title: Understanding personal finances: why it's an essential skill today
1.hook:
Personal finance management is rarely taught in school. Yet understanding your money is now an essential skill, just like knowing how to manage your time or develop professional skills.

Many people earn a decent living, but struggle to:
‚Ä¢ understand where their money goes,
‚Ä¢ make calm financial decisions,
‚Ä¢ or achieve their financial goals.

The good news? Personal finance can be learned.
sections: Why personal finance management isn't innate
Understanding your money to regain financial control
Personal finance is a skill that develops over time
Conclusion: learning to manage money permanently changes the relationship with money

2.title: Financial skill building: from confusion to steering your money
2.hook:
Many people feel like they "manage their money poorly." In reality, most don't manage poorly: they don't steer.

They sometimes check their balance, pay their bills, save when there's something left... but without a global vision or clear method.

The good news?
Financial management isn't binary. It's built step by step, like real skill development.
sections: From passive management to financial steering
Step 1: Observe your finances without judgment
Step 2: Structure to give meaning to numbers
Step 3: Understand gaps to make better decisions
Step 4: Decide based on your goals
Why financial skill building often fails
How Steero supports financial skill building
Conclusion: steering your finances is an accessible skill

3.title: Why no financial tool works without a ritual
3.hook:
Downloading a financial management app is easy. Checking it regularly... much less so.

It's not a lack of motivation. It's not a problem with financial intelligence either. The real breaking point is the absence of ritual.

Without ritual, even the best tool ends up forgotten. With a simple ritual, financial management finally becomes sustainable.
sections: The real problem with modern financial tools
Financial ritual: what are we really talking about?
Ritual as a pillar of financial skill building
How Steero was designed around ritual, not the tool
Conclusion: without ritual, there's no financial control

4.title: The 2-minute financial ritual: myth or reality?
4.hook:
When talking about financial management, many still imagine:
‚Ä¢ complex spreadsheets,
‚Ä¢ hours of analysis,
‚Ä¢ a discipline that's hard to maintain.

So the idea of a 2-minute financial ritual seems unrealistic. Not because 2 minutes isn't enough... but because financial management is often thought of as a single block, instead of a set of complementary rituals.
sections: Why financial management always seems too heavy
The key principle: one ritual = one purpose
Financial rituals: an architecture, not a constraint
Why the 2-minute ritual is not only possible, but essential
What a ritual-structured approach changes
Conclusion: it's not time that's missing, it's structure

5.title: Understanding your finances as a dashboard, not as punishment
5.hook:
If managing your money makes you uncomfortable, it's probably not because of the numbers. It's because of what they represent emotionally.

For many, looking at their finances means:
‚Ä¢ confronting past mistakes,
‚Ä¢ feeling guilty,
‚Ä¢ or feeling like being "scolded."

But what if you completely changed perspective? What if your finances became a dashboard, not a judgment?
sections: Why looking at finances is often experienced as punishment
A dashboard isn't there to judge, but to inform
Why visualization is such a powerful lever
From punishment to steering: a change of posture
How Steero helps you adopt this dashboard logic
Conclusion: looking at your finances should never be scary

6.title: The 50/30/20 rule: good foundation or false promise?
6.hook:
If you're at all interested in budget management, you've surely come across this rule:
‚Ä¢ 50% for needs,
‚Ä¢ 30% for wants,
‚Ä¢ 20% for savings.

Simple. Clear. Reassuring. But one question deserves to be asked: is it a real solution... or just a starting point?
sections: Why the 50/30/20 rule is so popular
Why the rule can become guilt-inducing
The real question to ask (that the rule doesn't ask)
The rule as a benchmark, not a goal
Adapt rather than apply: the key to a lasting budget
How Steero helps you go beyond the rule without throwing it away
Conclusion: a good rule never replaces understanding
